user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_monotonic_sec_counter:
```c
time_t
MHD_monotonic_sec_counter (void)
{
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME
  struct timespec ts;

  if ( (_MHD_UNWANTED_CLOCK != mono_clock_id) &&
       (0 == clock_gettime (mono_clock_id,
                            &ts)) )
    return ts.tv_sec - mono_clock_start;
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GETTIME */
#ifdef HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME
  if (_MHD_INVALID_CLOCK_SERV != mono_clock_service)
  {
    mach_timespec_t cur_time;

    if (KERN_SUCCESS == clock_get_time (mono_clock_service,
                                        &cur_time))
      return cur_time.tv_sec - mono_clock_start;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CLOCK_GET_TIME */
#if defined(_WIN32)
#if _WIN32_WINNT >= 0x0600
  if (1)
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) (GetTickCount64 () - tick_start)) / 1000);
#else  /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
  if (0 != perf_freq)
  {
    LARGE_INTEGER perf_counter;

    QueryPerformanceCounter (&perf_counter);   /* never fail on XP and later */
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) perf_counter.QuadPart - perf_start)
                     / perf_freq);
  }
#endif /* _WIN32_WINNT < 0x0600 */
#endif /* _WIN32 */
#ifdef HAVE_GETHRTIME
  if (1)
    return (time_t) (((uint64_t) (gethrtime () - hrtime_start)) / 1000000000);
#endif /* HAVE_GETHRTIME */

  return time (NULL) - sys_clock_start;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The function MHD_monotonic_sec_counter has no parameters (void), so Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified) cannot be violated within this function. All potentially mutable objects passed to other functions are either addresses of local variables (e.g., &ts for clock_gettime, &cur_time for clock_get_time, &perf_counter for QueryPerformanceCounter) or NULL (time(NULL)), and modifying the objects those pointers refer to is permitted by the rule — the prohibition is on modifying the parameter itself, not the pointee. The other inputs (mono_clock_id, mono_clock_service, perf_freq, tick_start, hrtime_start, mono_clock_start, sys_clock_start) are globals or constants used as arguments; this function does not assign to any of them. Therefore there are no fragments in this code that require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
